issue.title: Project folders / group projects
issue.body:
### Your Environment

* Operating System and version: macOS Catalina (Desktop version)
* App version: 5.6.2

### Imagined Behavior

**premable**: I always work on a lot of projects at the same time. I'm sure it's the same with many people.
The list in the sidebar can get pretty long and one does have to scroll around quite a bit to find things. Also there's projects on hold, or things that need to be archived and removed from SP but which are being kept for some reason.

**Possible solution**: Something that could make this whole thing much more usable could be having folders to group things into.
So I would for eg. group all the idle projects into a folder, close it and access it only when a project comes back to life.
These folders could work just like the parent "Project" folder, with a little arrow on the side to expand or collapse it.
What do you think?

comment.body:
@johannesjo First of all I should mention that the tool is great as is :D So thank you so much for maintaining this awesome project!

In order to avoid feature bloating, my recommendation is to add sections (could be implemented by dividers for example) to the left-hand-side menu with (maybe) collapse+expand feature. This way, at least one could see and distinguish the different sub-projects visually. I believe this not interfere with the simple use case.

issue.title: Dropbox sync occasionally returns 504 error on iOS devices
issue.body:
<!--- Your issue may already be reported!
!!! Please search the issues before creating one !!! -->

### Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* Version used: 6.0.1, Web
* Operating System and version: iOS 14.1
* Desktop Environment:
* Browser Name and version: Safari 14.1

### Expected Behavior
The Dropbox sync should work fine. I have tested this against the web app on Android (not the ones downloaded from Play Store)

### Current Behavior
The app returns **Unknown Sync Error: Error: Request failed with Status 504**.

### Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
<!--- Provide a link to a live example or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->
1. Open the web app on Safari
2. Add to Home Screen
3. Go to the app Settings (in PWA) to set up Dropbox sync
4. Try wait for 30 mins to 1 hour and try to synchronize again

### Console Output
<!--- Is there any output if you press Ctrl+Shift+i (Cmd+Alt+i for mac) in the console tab? If so please post it here. -->
Unfortunately, in order to get the console output I need to connect to a Mac device, which I don't have.

### Error Log (Desktop only)
<!--- For the desktop versions, there is also an error log file in case there is no console output. 
Usually, you can find it here:
on Linux: 
~/.config/superProductivity/log.log
--or--
~/snap/superproductivity/current/.config/superProductivity/log.log

on macOS: ~/Library/Logs/superProductivity/log.log

on Windows: %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Roaming\superProductivity\log.log
. -->

### Screenshot

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17312341/98012931-4336ef00-1e2c-11eb-9a3d-532a9f5fe72c.png)

issue.title: Allow projects to have default tags for created tasks
issue.body:
## Problem Statement

Certain projects I have fit within the scope of a tag, and I want to be able to track the tasks with that tag too. For example I have a project "Front Yard Stairs", which is under the tag "Yard work". Right now I have to edit the tag of each task as I make it (or use the `#` syntax which is very helpful). However it would be convenient if in the project settings I could specify default tags to be added automatically when I make a new task.

## :heavy_plus_sign: Additional context
#972 I think the suggestion here is also a solution, so long as projects use the same tags tasks do.

issue.title: Better visual organization
issue.body:
> I don't know if something like this has already been asked in pull requests because I couldn't find anything related, but here goes.

## Problem Statement
I use SuperProductivity for almost everything, but I miss some things.

The app is perfect when it comes to task organization, time management and task statistics. However, from my experience with it (I've been using it since 09/09/22 and evangelize its use to my friends, I practically became a fan lol) I end up noticing that when the use of simple tasks increases and I only work for various types of things — for example, I record practically all the tasks, even my sleep time and what I spent resting or preparing something, I always try to close the day with 24 hours spent and I monitor the types by tags — it ends up being "overloaded" in terms of visualization/interface.

I like to use the main (today) tab to orient myself through the day and know exactly what I have to do—thanks a lot for that, by the way. Thanks to the use of this app and other external things, I became an extremely productive and organized person :) — but since I have a lot of repetitive tasks (more than 20) and things that take less than 10 seconds to do, which are practically habits that I can't forget, this ends up weighing on the visualization.
Imagine your home tab with 25 tasks and you're just asking yourself "Fuck, what do I do?". You can even use features that exist — like automatic ordering based on numbers, which is something that I initially found very confusing and difficult to understand, but which later was a marvel for me — but every time you add something new or take something out, you have to rearrange several other numbers and go opening configuration by configuration. Shit, I can't add a new habit because it's hard work, it's discouraging... Or I can just not order it and leave it messy, which I ended up doing.

## :grey_question: Possible Solution

Anyway, being more exact and direct, I'll list some things that I think would make the application cleaner and much more efficient (even cerebrally speaking).

+ There should be graphical separators (for example, the behavior of the classic \<hr> tag) that can be added in the projects interface, tags and in the Today tab.

+ Being able to group tasks based on predefined configurations and dynamically (not only with a predefined configuration, but also "freely"). Ex: "I want to put the tasks that I demand all day and that only end at the end of the day in one place, so I'm going to create a folder and drag it inside it, perfect."

+ Some specific behaviors in bookmarks, so that it is possible to differentiate "continuous" tasks (of the whole day) from occasional and quick tasks (done in a moment), such as: "Did I create a folder for continuous tasks? special tag and they go to that folder automatically!"


And finally, there's something that I think probably other people have also suffered from, but this is outside of that visual context that I talked about in the whole pr, but functional.
Moving from one day to the next, the closing of the day ends up being “lost” when you forget to close at the end of the previous day. That is, I end up not evaluating myself because I forgot to close for the day, and doing that the next day at 6 am is impossible, as I would be closing on the second day and not the first...


Anyway, thank you very much for your attention and for creating this beautiful application that supports me every day. It would be perfect if I could contribute financially or even with code, but it's not within my current possibilities, although I really want to :(

comment.body: This issue has not received any updates in 90 days. Please comment, if this still relevant!

issue.title: Second brain with Super Productivity
issue.body:
## Problem Statement
Sometimes finding notes accross multiple projects and tasks is hard. Even more when you need to connect the dots between different tasks or projects.

You then need to cycle through all your project's notes which is tedious as there is no search function implemented. But then you still need to connect all relations in your head w/o a graphical view of the interconnectivity of certain ideas.

## :grey_question: Possible Solution
There are several apps available on the web, e.g. [Obsidian](https://www.obsidian.md) which saves your notes as a markdown file within a given directory.

If Super Productivity would use the same directory for saving/syncing the task's notes, you could combine both applications with ease. You don't even need a costly ObsidianSync for that.

## Implementation idea
Sync the Super Productvity internal notes with a named directory where markdown files are placed. A project would then relate to a subdirectory (e.g. project name = subdir name) and any notes will be placed there. If additional notes are found, show them too.

comment.body: The feature would still be nice

issue.title: Consider adding Trello Integration
issue.body:
Hi,  this is a feature request rather than a bug. 

My company uses Trello a fair bit, but I enjoy the deep persistence (nagging?) of the Super Productivity reminders.  :-)  An integration with Trello would allow me to add the scheduled reminders/etc from your interface, but also give some transparency to the Trello board.  It also allows my manager to easily drop tasks into the shared Trello board and I won't miss them due the the task sync from Super Productivity.

Note,  Google Keep/Other integration Hub might allow for a multi-step hop integration so if you have any ideas for a non-code workaround I'm open to them.

Sincerely,
R

pull_request.title: fix: focus after marking last subtask done (#2795)
pull_request.body:
# Description

Hello there.

These changes should help resolve how the application focuses the first task of a task list if the last subtask of another task is marked as done via the tick button. The resulting behaviour should put it in line with how the focus travels when resolving the subtask using a keyboard shortcut instead. 

I've also added an E2E test to cover this particular scenario. I'm not all too familiar with how this works with Nightwatch, but I gave it my best shot.

As an aside, there's another usability niggle (opinionated) I've noticed, but I don't have any good ideas for how to improve it.

If one marks a task with subtasks as done, then the focus doesn't move to the next sibling task in the same list. Underneath the hood, the application tries to shift the focus to the first subtask. However, because of how that entire task will end up in the completed pile, the focus disappears altogether, creating some disorientation.

I think the above is exacerbated by how the default behaviour of keyboard scrolling down a task list will automatically move into subtask items from parent task items. As long as this latter behaviour is required, I can't see an easy intervention.

In any case, happy to amend whatever.

![demo1](https://github.com/johannesjo/super-productivity/assets/43751307/8ab5a2c4-67f8-4493-8112-596091be1e3f)

## Issues Resolved

#2795

## Check List

- [ ] New functionality includes testing. (N/A)
- [ ] New functionality has been documented in the README if applicable. (N/A)

issue.title: Schedule repeated (daily, weekly..) events and breaks
issue.body:
Hello, here is an idea based on my very recent experience

## Problem Statement
I go to lunch everyday (a big break) from 12:00 to 14:00. Right now there is no way to reflect that clearly in Super Productivity - in particular, the Timeline assumes you work non-stop from the start of your day to the end.

Another problem: I have weekly meetings that happen each given day at a specific time. It is possible to schedule them as repeated task, but you still have to click on "Start task" or fill up the time spent manually.

## :grey_question: Possible Solution
Make it possible to describe scheduled breaks or events.

We could imagine getting a "nature" menu where you could select "task", "break", or "event", with the following semantics:
  - a task is what exists already
  - a break is a task that automatically starts (unless another task was started). This time does not count towards the time worked ; instead it counts on the time spent on break.
  - an event is like a break (it automatically starts), except that the time is counted as working time

## :arrow_heading_up: Describe alternatives you've considered
Not really alternatives but rather workarounds:
- I scheduled a daily task that is called "Eating". Super Productivity will think I did not spend any time on that task although I did have a break. I am using Pomodoro Timer so I can't really turn on Break mode for an indefinite amount of time neither.
- I scheduled a weekly task for my weekly meeting. It works nice, but I do have to click Run or to fill up the time myself manually, or else the app thinks I did not work.

If there is some feature I did not notice that would solve these problems, I am all ears

Thanks a lot for all the work put into that software, I like it a lot so far!
